#â€‹698 â€” July 25, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Astro 4.12: Say Hello to Server Islands â€” The flexible Astro framework for building modern content-based sites continues to go from strength to strength. v4.12 includes a new concept of server islands, a way to integrate static HTML and server-side generated componentsÂ together.

Erika and Phillips (Astro)

Whatâ€™s New for JavaScript Developers in ECMAScript 2024 â€” High level analysis of developments in the ECMAScript spec, with insights from Ecma vice president Daniel Ehrenberg, TC39 co-chair Rob Palmer, and developer Ashley Claymore. A good, thoroughÂ roundup of the state ofÂ play.

Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

ğŸ’¡ If you want to go a step further with what's coming up next, Igalia presents a summary of the recent TC39 meeting in Helsinki with which language proposals were advanced andÂ discussed.

Level Up Your Next.js Skills â€” Join Scott Moss for this detailed video course on intermediate Next.js. Learn how to build production-ready apps by diving into concepts such as server actions, data fetching, protected routes, form authentication, performance caching, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

A Post Mortem of What Broke Node v22.5.0 â€” Node's â€˜Currentâ€™ release line gives access to the latest Node has to offer, at the risk of encountering troublesome bugs too â€“ v22.5 included two, alas, with Node v22.5.1 quickly following to resolveÂ them.

Yagiz Nizipli et al.

IN BRIEF:

  • Rich Harris provides some details about the forthcoming Svelte 5 and shares his opinions on React ServerÂ Components (he thinks they're "prettyÂ phenomenal").

  • Node.js has added an experimental feature to strip TypeScript types from the code it runs.

  • ğŸ“Š The results of the State of React 2023 survey have been released including insights from over 13,000Â respondents, as have the results of Stack Overflow's 2024 developer survey.

RELEASES:

  • Mikro ORM 6.3 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js and TypeScript, now with an optional 'schema-first'Â approach.

  • Uppy 4.0 â€“ Powerful, modular JavaScript fileÂ uploader.

  • Preact 10.23 â€“ The 3KB React compatibleÂ alternative.

  • Node.js v20.16.0 (LTS), Storybook 8.2, pnpm 9.6, Meteor.js 3

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

So You Think You Know Box Shadows? â€” The author indulges his creative side with some fun experiments into what he calls â€œsome of the worst possible thingsâ€ you can do with box shadows on a DIV element, coupled with JavaScript.

David Gerrells

â–¶Â Â Don't Use JS for That: Moving Features to CSS and HTML â€” Packed with code and examples. Some techniques arenâ€™t universally supported yet, but thereâ€™s a lot that the browser can offer that you donâ€™t need to reimplement yourself, like color picking, modals, andÂ animations.

Kilian Valkhof

ğŸ˜˜ Kiss Bugs Goodbye â€” Get 80% automated E2E test coverage in just 4 months with QA Wolf. With QA cycles complete in minutes (not days), bugs donâ€™t stand a chance. Schedule aÂ demo.

QA Wolf sponsor

How to Choose the Best Rendering Strategy for Your App â€” The differences between Static Site Generation (SSG), Server-Side Rendering (SSR), Client-Side Rendering (CSR), Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR), and Partial Prerendering (PPR).

Alice Alexandra Moore (Vercel)

A Practical Guide to Not Blocking the Event Loop â€” A look at the core principles of synchronous and asynchronous work in a single-threaded environment, stressing the importance of non-blocking code for efficient event loopÂ utilization.

Slava Knyazev

Why is Spawning a New Process in Node So Slow? â€” The developers of the Val Town platform noticed that Node couldnâ€™t spawn more than 40 external processes per second, whereas Deno and Bun could do a lotÂ more..

Max McDonnell

Debugging Your Node.js Project with Sentry â€” Join us live today to learn all the basics to monitoring and debugging your Node.js projects withÂ Sentry.

Sentry sponsor

ğŸ“º How to Engineer Your Developer Blog Posts to Have Bigger Impact â€“ From a Postgres community perspective, but the advice is universal and wellÂ explained. Claire Giordano

ğŸ“„ Bring Your Own API Key: Supporting User-Provided OpenAI Keys and Prompts in Browser Extensions Stephen Siegert

ğŸ“„ How to Review Code Effectively: A GitHub Staff Engineerâ€™s Philosophy Sarah Vessels (GitHub)

ğŸ“„ How Airbnb Smoothly Upgrades React â€“ It was no small task. Andre Wiggins (Airbnb)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Ky: Tiny, Elegant Fetch-Based HTTP Client for Browsers â€” Makes the Fetch API tidier to use as shown here. If you want to tighten up your fetch calls, it's worth aÂ look.

Sindre Sorhus

React Native Filament: A 3D Rendering Engine for React Native â€” Fast, native 3D rendering with a React touch. Rendering takes place on a separate thread for efficiency. GitHub repo and pretty good docs, too.

Marc Rousavy

Tests Are Dead. Meticulous Is Here â€” Automatically creates & maintains e2e UI tests. Zero flakes. Backed by YC, CTO of GitHub, CPO of Adobe, CEO ofÂ Vercel.

Meticulous sponsor

Git Granary: A Personal Git LFS Server â€” A Deno-powered (but can run under Bun and Node) Git Large File Storage (LFS) server implementation written in TypeScript for self-hosted personal useÂ cases.

David Bushell

litegraph.js: A Graph Node Engine and Editor â€” Useful if you need to create a system for users to create and manipulate graphs or interconnecting â€˜nodesâ€™ for things like graphics, audio or data pipelines. Demo.

Javi Agenjo

  • ğŸ¤– OpenAI Node v4.53.0 â€“ The official Node library for OpenAI's API adds support for their newest gpt-4o-miniÂ model.

  • Rollup 4.19 â€“ The ES moduleÂ bundler gains support forÂ decorators.

  • eslint-plugin-unicorn 55.0 â€“ 100+ useful ESLint rules in oneÂ place.

  • eslint-plugin-promise 7.0 â€“ Enforce best practices forÂ promises.

  • pretty-ms 9.1 â€“ Convert milliseconds to a human readable string.

  • Tinybase 5.1 â€“ Powerful reactive data store for localâ€‘firstÂ apps.

  • MiniSearch 7.1 â€“ In-memory fulltext search engine.Â (Demo.)

  • swup 4.7 â€“ Page transition library for server-renderedÂ sites.

  • Jasmine 5.2 â€“ Testing framework for browsers &Â Node.

ã€

#â€‹696 â€” July 11, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

es-toolkit: A Modern JavaScript Utility Library â€” Think Lodash but newer, faster, smaller, and with tree shaking and built-in TypeScript support. The reference guide shows off the supported functions so far â€“ itâ€™s not quite as extensive as Lodash, but itâ€™s getting there with the goal being â€œto achieve full feature parity withÂ Lodash.â€

Viva Republica, Inc

What's Coming Next for ESLint â€” At eleven years old, ESLint is preparing itself for another eleven years by continuing to evolve into a language-agnostic linter that anyone can write plugins for. The new configuration system introduced in ESLint 9.0 is â€œjust the beginning of significant changesâ€ on theÂ way.

Nicholas C. Zakas

Cut Code Review Time & Bugs in Half with AI â€” AI-first pull request reviewer that offers context-aware, line-by-line feedback, and smart chat. Trusted by 1000's of developers, itâ€™s the most installed AI app on GitHub and GitLab marketplaces. Start your seven-day free trial today! It's forever free for open-sourceÂ projects.

CodeRabbit sponsor

Speeding up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Isolated Declarations â€” â€œTypeScriptâ€™s new isolated declaration feature is a game changer for sharing code among developers.â€ The latest in Marvinâ€™s fantastic series about finding performance wins in how we do things in the JSÂ world.

Marvin Hagemeister

IN BRIEF:

  • â–¶ï¸ A side-by-side comparison of publishing a module to npm vs JSR.

  • ğŸ™ï¸ Vue creator Evan You went on the DejaVue podcast to talk about the last ten years of Vue.

  • ğŸ—£ï¸ JavaScript-powered text-to-speech in the browser is getting veryÂ good.

  • Efforts are being made to integrate SQLite into Node.js.

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 9.5 â€“ The efficiency-focused package manager introduces Catalogs, a way to have shareable dependency version specifiers.

  • Node.js v22.4.1 (Current), v20.15.1 (LTS) and v18.20.4 (LTS)

  • Deno 1.45, Angular 18.1

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Recreating the THX 'Deep Note' in JavaScript â€” A fun bit of sound generation with Tone.js. Note that people have reported mixed results on different browsers, but it works for me. Just be careful it doesnâ€™t â–¶ï¸Â explodeÂ yourÂ teeth.

Alexander Keliris

Introducing @let in Angular â€” The new @let syntax extends Angularâ€™s built-in template syntax with a better way to define variables inside componentÂ templates.

Mark Thompson and Kristiyan Kostadinov

Building a Hybrid Sign-Up/Subscribe Form with Stripe Elements â€” A practical guide on how to use custom flows, webhooks, and user metadata to build a single form that automatically subscribes new users using StripeÂ Elements.

Clerk sponsor

Sneaky React Memory Leaks: How the React Compiler Wonâ€™t Save You â€” While the new and exciting React Compiler can tackle a lot of issues and make most codebases more performant, it pays to be aware of tricky edgeÂ cases.

Kevin Schiener

ğŸ“„ Resizing and Transferring ArrayBuffers â€“ Dr. Axel continues his exploration of ECMAScriptÂ 2024. Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ Protecting Against Third Party Code Changes with Script Integrity Chris Coyier

ğŸ“„ How to Create a Chrome Extension with Vanilla JavaScript Esther Vaati

ğŸ“„ Learn React Suspense by Building a Suspense-Enabled Library Slava Knyazev

ğŸ“„ Running a Successful Meetup â€“ From the team behind Remix. Bob Ziroll

ğŸ“„ Moving from Express to Fastify Tom MacWright (Val Town)

React Flow 12: Create Node-Based Editors & Interactive Diagrams â€” Part of xyflow, this makes it easy to create node-based UIs where you have interactive components wired together however youÂ choose. There's a Svelte versionÂ too.

Moritz Klack and John Robb

â¤ï¸ Loving console.log Is Easy, but Hate ğŸ˜¡ Losing Context to View Messy Output â€” Developer productivity tools Wallaby.js, Quokka.js and Console Ninja show console.log values and errors right next to yourÂ code.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Croner 8.1: 'Cron' Triggering and Evaluation â€” Trigger functions to the schedule of your choice using cron syntax. It can also evaluate cron expressions to give you a list of upcomingÂ times.

Hexagon

TinyBase 5.0: A Reactive Data Store for Local-First Apps â€” A data store that acts as a reactive backend to your apps if you want less headache building out backends. v5.0 includes a new mergeableStore type that can wrap your data as a Conflict-Free Replicated Data Type (CRDT). Homepage.

James Pearce

PLV8: Use JavaScript Functions in PostgreSQL â€” Did you know you can use JavaScript within Postgres for things like stored procedures and triggers? PLV8 is the extension that makes it happen. PLV8ify adds an extra layer by converting JS/TS files into PLV8 readyÂ SQL.

PLV8JS Development Group

ğŸ˜˜ Kiss Bugs Goodbye â€” Get 80% automated E2E coverage in just 4 months with QA Wolf. With QA cycles complete in minutes (not days), bugs donâ€™t stand a chance. Schedule aÂ demo.

QA Wolf sponsor

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹697 â€” July 18, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Exploring JS: JavaScript Books for Programmers â€” Youâ€™ll know Dr. Axel from his fantastic blog posts over the years, or his once tenure as JavaScript Weeklyâ€™s editor, but he also has an impressive array of no-nonsense books that you can mostly read for free online, including the newly updated Exploring JavaScript (ES2024 Edition), Deep JavaScript, and TacklingÂ TypeScript.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Node.js v22.5.0 (Current) Released â€” A notable release for two reasons: first, the WebSocket feature in node:http is now exposed, but second, Node is embedding SQLite and now offers direct access to it via node:sqlite.

Antoine du Hamel

WorkOS: The Modern Identity Platform for B2BÂ SaaS â€” Start selling to enterprise customers with just a few lines of code. WorkOS provides flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and RBAC in minutes. It's used by hundreds of high-growth startups including Perplexity, Vercel, Drata, &Â Webflow.

WorkOS sponsor

â–¶Â Â The Talks from dotJS 2024 â€” dotJS 2024 took place in Paris a few months ago, and now all the talks are available on YouTube. Highlights include Lea Verou talking about the parallels between API and UI design, David Flanagan on advancements in WebAssembly, and Minko Gechev on convergence of features in modern frameworks The talks are all short, so the takeaways are quick toÂ get.

YouTube

IN BRIEF:

  • The annual JS1024 JavaScript golfing competition is currently running with submissions due tomorrow. You have to build a JavaScript demo in just 1KB and there are lots of links to tools and tutorials there toÂ help.

  • The first beta of TypeScript 5.6 is expected next week â€“ here's the TypeScript 5.6 iteration plan if you want to get ahead on the features andÂ schedule.

RELEASES:

  • ESLint v9.7.0 â€“Â Supports ES2025 duplicate capturing groups inÂ regexes. Duy Ng also shares some tips on migrating to ESLint 9+.

  • Boa 0.19 â€“ A JS engine written in Rust for embedding in otherÂ projects.

  • Meteor 3.0 â€“ Full-stack framework for real-timeÂ apps.

  • jQuery 4.0 Beta 2, htmx 2.0.1, swc 1.7

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Make Complex Chrome Extensions â€” Spinning up a quick, simple browser extension isnâ€™t that big of a deal nowadays, especially with tools like Extension to kick off a project. Larger extensions are a different story, so itâ€™s neat to learn from the experiences of a team thatâ€™s builtÂ one.

Nina Torgunakova

Build a Task Manager with Next.js, Neon, & Clerk that Isolates Tasks to Specific Teams â€” Learn to build a multi-tenant task manager that solves team isolation, user role management, and authenticationÂ challenges.

Clerk sponsor

A TypeScripter's Take on Zig â€” Rust might be the cool systems language on the block right now, but Zig has a lot going for it too (Bun, notably, is implemented in it.) A good primer from a TypeScriptÂ perspective.

Dan Vanderkam

How Fast is JavaScript? Simulating 20 Million Particles â€” â€œThe challenge: simulate 1,000,000 particles in plain JavaScript at 60 FPS on a phone using only the CPU. Letâ€™s go.â€ The sort of fun, detailed experimentation Iâ€™ll alwaysÂ support.

David Gerrells

A Guide to Reading and Writing Node.js Streams â€” Matteo reminds us of the benefits of using Nodeâ€™s powerful streaming data features, where they make sense, and how to handle back-pressure and errorÂ management.

Matteo Collina

ViteConf Is Back! â€” ViteConf will be returning to the virtual stage on October 3rd. Get your ticketsÂ now.

StackBlitz sponsor

What React Devs Need to Know About ReactÂ Native â€” While React and React Native share many similarities, theyâ€™re different under the hood. Hereâ€™s some of what you need to know to make theÂ transition.

Kadi Kraman (Expo)

ğŸ“„ NPM Supply Chain Security: Why We Can Be Optimistic About theÂ Future Robat William

ğŸ“„ How to Create Distortion and Grain Effects on Scroll with Shaders in Three.js Jan Kohlbach

ğŸ“„ How to Build a JavaScript UI Component-First DevTool Startup in 2024 Corbado

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Poku 2.0: A Cross-Platform Test Runner for JS â€” Pokuâ€™s philosophy is to â€˜bring the JavaScript essence back to testing.â€™ It runs the same way across Node, Bun and Deno, and auto-detects ESM, CommonJS andÂ TypeScript.

Weslley AraÃºjo

InfiniteGrid 4.12: Arrange Card Elements Infinitely in a Grid Layout â€” A mature and established way to create grids formed of card elements of varying sizes. Happy on both desktop and mobile and has integrations for React, Vue, Angular, Svelte, and others. GitHubÂ repo.

NAVER

ğŸ¤–Â Micro Agent: An AI Agent That Writes Code for You â€” A Node.js-based tool that takes the approach of writing a test case first and then iterates upon a solution until the testsÂ pass.

Builderâ€¤io

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to yourÂ billionth.

Render sponsor

Hyphenopoly 6.0: A Polyfill for Client-Side Hyphenation â€” Hyphenates text if the user agent or language doesn't support CSS hyphenation (a feature thatâ€™s part of Baseline but with widely varying support). An interesting use ofÂ WebAssembly.

Mathias Nater

simplex-noise.js: A Fast Simplex Noise Implementation â€” Small, self contained, and fast, and you can use it in cool demos like this or for applying convincing grain/noise to images or other data, say.

Jonas Wagner

Maska 3.0: Zero-Dependency Input Mask Library â€” Several demos on the homepage. Lightweight and framework independent but offers Vue 2/3, Alpine.js and Svelte integrations. GitHubÂ repo.

Formâ€¤io

  • Wasp 0.14 â€“ Wasp is a Rails-like framework for React, Node.js andÂ Prisma.

  • PKI.js 3.2 â€“ Pure JS library for working with public key oriented systems. Certificates, signing,Â etc.

  • ğŸ“· Vision Camera 4.5 â€“ Advanced camera control for ReactÂ Native.

  • AlaSQL.js 4.5 â€“ Isomorphic JavaScript SQLÂ database.

item.title: ã€How Googlebot sees your JavaScriptã€‘Googlebot å¦‚ä½•æŸ¥çœ‹æ‚¨çš„ JavaScript
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹699 â€” August 1, 2024

Read on the Web

ğŸ–ï¸ Hi! Just a quick note to say that we're taking next week off for a brief summer break. We'll be back with our next issue on August 15.
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process â€” Once, if you wanted Google to index your content, it needed to be right in the HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have changed, but how much? MERJ and Vercel analyzed over 100,000 Googlebot fetches in an attempt to empirically demystify Googleâ€™sÂ approach.

Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

Garbage Collection and Closures â€” When three JavaScript experts get together and all learn something new about how JavaScript works when they encounter a memory leak, it pays to listen. An interesting quirk to be awareÂ of.

Jake Archibald

Tracing: Frontend Issues with Backend Solutions â€” As Developers, we often hear complaints like, â€œThis page is taking too long to load. Itâ€™s a front-end issue. Fix it.â€ But what if the problem isnâ€™t on the front end? How do you trace issues through your stack? Watch the step by stepÂ guide.

Sentry sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 5.6 Beta â€” The first beta of the next major version of TypeScript is out. Region-prioritized diagnostics (VS Code only, for now) is a particularly interestingÂ addition.

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

IN BRIEF:

  • Porffor is an experimental ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler/runtime that compiles to either WASM or native. Its developer has just gone full time on the project thanks to support from GitHub co-founder ChrisÂ Wanstrath.

  • React Conf 2024 has shared all the talks from its Las Vegas event back inÂ May.

  • Ryan Dahl explains what Deno got wrong about HTTP imports and how it's movingÂ forward.

RELEASES:

  • Bun 1.1.21 â€“ The JavaScriptCore-based server-side JavaScript runtime improves its Node.js and RemixÂ compatibility.

  • Node.js v20.16.0 (LTS)

  • ESLint v9.8.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Benchmarking AWS Lambda Cold Starts Across JS Runtimes â€” Itâ€™s from the Deno team so it may not be surprising that Deno was fastest, but they share their methodology and results for Deno, Node, Bun and AWSâ€™s managed Node runtime and they weren't all that farÂ apart.

Zinkovsky and Jiang (Deno)

Node.js's Experimental Support for TypeScript â€” In this pull request, Node merged an experimental ability to transpile TypeScript into JavaScript, ultimately letting Node directly â€˜run TypeScriptâ€™. No type checking is performed and, as Matt Pocock explains, TypeScript-only features are a no-go.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

Ever Felt Compelled to Answer with Certainty When You Werenâ€™tÂ Sure? â€” Donâ€™t stifle innovation with this toxic behavior. Thoughts on how to fix thisâ€”as a leader or individualÂ contributor.

Test Double sponsor

A Different Way to Think About TypeScript â€” â€œa very expressive way to operate over sets, and using those sets to enforce strict compile timeÂ checksâ€

Robby Pruzan

ğŸ“„ Reading from the Clipboard in JavaScript Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ Why Unknown Types Are Useful â€“ TypeScriptâ€™s unknown, specifically. Michael Uloth

ğŸ“„ Flexible Network Data Preloading in Large SPAs Matteo Mazzarolo

ğŸ”ˆ Why the Creator of jQuery Uses React and TypeScript Syntaxâ€¤fm

ğŸ“„ Highlights from Git 2.46 Taylor Blau (GitHub)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

emoji-picker-element: A Lightweight Emoji Picker â€” An emoji picking control, packaged as a Web Component. You can also add custom emoji to it. GitHubÂ repo.

Nolan Lawson

STRICH: Fast and Reliable 1D/2D JS Barcode Scanning in YourÂ Browser â€” You donâ€™t need a native app to scan barcodes! Try the free demo app or sign up for the free, full-featured 30-dayÂ trial.

STRICH sponsor

â˜ï¸Â International Telephone Input â€” A very mature option that offers all the trimmings youâ€™d expect: accessibility, type definitions, flags, automatic country selection, automatic formatting, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Jack O'Connor

PythonMonkey: Embed a JavaScript Engine into the Python VM â€” If you need to use Python but want to run JS, this gives you a way to do it with Mozillaâ€™s SpiderMonkey engine. It now supports the CommonJS module systemÂ too.

Distributive Corp.

ğŸ“…Â Calendar Link: Dynamically Generate Event Links for Calendars â€” Generate event links for Google Calendar, Yahoo Calendar, Outlook, etc.

Anand Chowdhary

The Only Production-Ready AI-Powered Backend Code Generator â€” Build new services, extend your existing applications with Amplication AI. Go from idea to production in fourÂ minutes.

Amplication sponsor

JS-PyTorch: A PyTorch-Like Library for JavaScript â€” Recently renamed from JS-Torch, this brings some of the magic from Pythonâ€™s popular PyTorch library to JavaScript for training and testing neural networks in particular. We linked to it earlier this year, but it has added GPU support thanks to GPU.js.

Eduardo Leao

json-to-csv-export: Generate Downloadable CSV of JSON Data â€” Youâ€™ve got some data in JSON, you want users to be able to download a CSV of that data.. GitHubÂ repo.

Coston Perkins

  • React Virtuoso 4.8 â€“ Complete React virtualized rendering list/table/grid family of components. Now with horizontal listÂ support.

  • ğŸ¨ Chroma.js 2.6 â€“ Simple color manpiulation library, now with tint and shadeÂ functions.

  • Ky 1.5 â€“ Simple HTTP client based upon Fetch for browsers, NodeÂ &Â Deno.

  • YouTube.js 10.2 â€“ Unofficial client for YouTube's internalÂ API.

  • tween.js 25.0 â€“ JavaScript/TypeScript animation engine.

  • ArangoJS 9.0 â€“ Driver for the ArangoDB graphÂ database.

  • is-online 11.0 â€“ Check if the Internet isÂ reachable.

  • sql.js 1.11 â€“ SQLite compiled toÂ JavaScript.

ğŸ¥³Â And a bit of fun..

p5.js is a popular â€˜creative codingâ€™ library that takes a lot of inspiration from Processing. p5 makes it easy to create digital art and interactive experiences without a lot of boilerplate (check out how simple this 'smoke particles' demo is, for example).

p5.js v1.10.0 has just landed, but the reason I wanted to mention it is because of how much fun I've had throwing AI generated code at the online p5 editor, and if you have access to tools like ChatGPT, you can do it too.

For example, give ChatGPT a prompt like:

Write some p5.js code that renders the JavaScript "JS" logo.

Copy and paste the result into the editor, and:

It's not perfect, but it's pretty good for a first try (and easy to 'fix' by hand).

Different LLMs take totally different approaches. Consider what Anthropic's Claude 3.5 gave me, for example:

Eeek..

Well, anyway, there's a lot of fun to be had, and you can prompt LLMs to improve the results or customize things as you wish. Have some fun with it, it's pretty cool what you can produce.

We're taking a week off now, but will be back on August 15!
